newsitem.title: USA: South Carolina Senate votes to cut tax on cars. [CORRECTED 22:10 GMT]
newsitem.headline: South Carolina Senate votes to cut tax on cars. [CORRECTED 22:10 GMT]

text.p: The South Carolina Senate voted unanimously to eliminate the property tax on cars by 2004, a legislative aide said Thursday.

The tax is calculated by multiplying 10.5 percent of the car's fair market value by the local property tax rate (corrects tax rate) , with the revenue divided among cities, counties and school districts.
The tax raised $408 million last year.
It would be phased out under the Senate plan, beginning with a cut of 12.5 percent or $49 million in fiscal 1999.
Supporters said the proposal would spur new car sales, increasing sales tax revenues enough to offset the property tax cut. It still must be approved in the House.
Last year, the House agreed to let voters decide whether to raise the sales tax to offset elimination of the car tax, but the proposal died in a conference committee.
